case_name: Bombay Port Trust v. New Great Insurance Co.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 342 of 1972 appealed by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated 16th September 1972 in Civil Revision No. 263 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 342 of 1972. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 16th September, 1972 of the High Court of Bombay in Civil Revision No. 263 of 1967.

facts.text: Petty claim for Rs. 1147.42 by first plaintiff (consignee) and second plaintiff (insurer New Great Insurance Co.) against Bombay Port Trust.

anchor.surface_text: A small cause involving a petty claim of Rs. 1147.42 has sailed slowly into the Supreme Court by special leave. Both sides-The Bombay Port Trust, appellant, and the New Great Insurance Co.

facts.text: Consignment of 53 bundles of mild steel plates despatched by Japanese exporter to Bombay port, entitled to first plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: A relevant diary of facts and dates will help focus attention on the primary legal question. The first plaintiff became entitled to claim a consignment of 53 bundles of mild steel plates despatched by a Japanese exporter to be delivered at the port of Bombay.

facts.text: Goods discharged into custody of Bombay Port Trust on September 12, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The goods were discharged in the docks into the custody of the. Bombay Port Trust  the defendant, and number the appellant  on September 12, 1959.

facts.text: Delivery of goods applied for on September 19, 1959, but only 52 bundles given.

anchor.surface_text: Within a week, that is, on September 19,1959, delivery of the goods was applied for and was given but of only 52 bundles.

facts.text: First plaintiff demanded missing bundle, Port Trust letters on September 29, October 10, and December 4, 1959 assuring search in progress.

anchor.surface_text: A week thereafter, the first plaintiff demanded the missing bundle, but was tenta- lisingly put off from time to time by the defendant by letters of September 29, October 10, and December 4, 1959 assuring that a search was in progress to trace the goods.

facts.text: Plaintiffs letter on September 26, 1959 sought information on missing bundle whereabouts.

anchor.surface_text: It is important at this stage to notice that the plaintiffs letter of September 26, 1959 sought information regarding the whereabouts of the above bundle so as to enable us to clear the same at an early date.

facts.text: Indian Maritime Enterprises letter dated November 7, 1959 confirmed all 53 bundles unloaded.

anchor.surface_text: Significantly the first plaintiff inquired of the Indian Maritime Enterprises, the agents of the Japanese vessel, whether the entire consignment of 53 bundles bad been duly landed. The reply received by the first plaintiff is meaningful in that the Indian Maritime Enterprises in there letter dated November 7, 1959, told the first plaintiff that all the 53 bundles had been duly unloaded.

facts.text: Port Trust informed on December 4, 1959 that missing bundle still under search.

anchor.surface_text: of course, the inquiry Section of the Alexandra Dock of the defendant indifferently informed the first plaintiff even on December 4, 1959 that the missing bundle was still under search and a definite reply regarding the out-turn of that item could be given only later when loading sheets were fully checked.

facts.text: First plaintiff letter December 5, 1959 to Port Trust noting vessel agents confirmation of landing and seeking confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: However, the first plaintiff by letter dated December 5, 1959 wrote to the port authorities that he had been informed by the agents of the vessel  The Indian Maritime Enterprises  that the entire 53 bundles had been landed and desired to please let us know immediately whether the bundle has been landed if landed let the, information regarding the whereabouts and, if not, kindly confirm the short landings.

facts.text: Port Trust informed on January 22, 1960 that bundle out-turned as landed but missing.

anchor.surface_text: Long later, on January 22, 1960, the Port Trust informed the first plaintiff that the bundle under reference had been out-turned as landed but missing.

facts.text: Non-delivery certificate issued on March 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Such a certificate was issued on March 1, 1960 and-on May 12, 1960 a statutory notice under S. 87 of the Act was issued,

facts.text: Statutory notice under S. 87 issued on May 12, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Such a certificate was issued on March 1, 1960 and-on May 12, 1960 a statutory notice under S. 87 of the Act was issued, followed on June 18, 1960 by the suit

facts.text: Suit filed on June 18, 1960 in Court of Small Causes for value of missing bundle.

anchor.surface_text: followed on June 18, 1960 by the suit for the missing bundle or its value by way of damages.

facts.text: Small Causes Court held defendant negligent, rejected limitation plea, decreed for plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: That Court held on the merits that the defendant had been negligent in bestowing the basic care which as statutory bailee it was bound to take, and on the preliminary plea of bar of limitation repelled it,

facts.text: Full Court in appeal set aside decree, held claim barred by limitation under s.87 Bombay Port Trust Act.

anchor.surface_text: The decrees passed was, however, set aside by the Full Court in appeal which held the claim to fall within the ambit of the lesser limitation laid down by the Act, and so beyond time.

facts.text: Bombay High Court single Judge upset limitation finding, directed disposal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The teetering course of the case brought success to the plaintiffs in the High Court when a single Judge upset the finding on limitation and directed disposal of the appeal on the merits.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds suit governed by s.87 Bombay Port Trust Act, 6 months limitation applies to short delivery.

anchor.surface_text: The logical conclusion of the legal study is that the short delivery of one bundle or rather the act of under-delivery in purported discharge of the bailees obligation under S. 61B of the Act is covered by s. 87 and the truncated limitation prescribed thereunder will apply.

facts.text: Cause of action accrues when consignee knows goods landed in port; here November 7, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the starting point of limitation arose on November 7, 1959 and the suit was instituted on June 18, 1960, a little over 10 days beyond the period of limitation.

facts.text: Suit instituted more than 6 months after November 7, 1959, hence barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the starting point of limitation arose on November 7, 1959 and the suit was instituted on June 18, 1960, a little over 10 days beyond the period of limitation. The plaintiffs thus missed the bus

facts.text: Second plaintiff insurer subrogated to first plaintiff's rights after paying value of lost goods.

anchor.surface_text: The second plaintiff, insurer, having paid the value of the lost articles to the first plaintiff got itself subrogated to the latters right, and they together laid the suit before the Court of Small Causes.

facts.text: Both parties agree facts but dispute limitation point affecting business community and Port Trust.

anchor.surface_text: Both sides-The Bombay Port Trust, appellant, and the New Great Insurance Co.  a nationalised institution , the companytesting respondent-agree before us that while there is only a short point of law in the case, a large section of the business community, as well as the Port Trust,

facts.text: Litigation took 15 years for this small commercial cause.

anchor.surface_text: Although the Court in this case is enquiring whether the little delay alleged legally disentitles the plaintiff to claim the value of the lost goods, it is a bathetic sidelight that the judicial process has limped along for 15 years

facts.text: Port Trust as statutory bailee under ss.151,152,161 Indian Contract Act per s.61B Bombay Port Trust Act.

anchor.surface_text: 61B. The responsibility of the Board for the loss, destruction or deterioration of goods of which it has taken charge shall, subject to the other provisions of this Act and subject also in the case of goods received for carriage by railways to the provisions of the Indian Railways Act,

facts.text: Owner must remove goods within 7 days of landing per s.61A Bombay Port Trust Act, else at owner's risk.

anchor.surface_text: S. 61A 1 . The Board shall, immediately upon the landing of any goods, take charge thereof, except as may be otherwise provided in the bye-laws, and store such as are liable in their opinion to suffer from exposure in any shed or warehouse belonging to the Board.

issues.text: Is the period so brief as six months in terms of s. 87 of the Bombay Port Trust Act, 1879 hereinafter called the Act, and if so, does time begin to run within around a week of the landing of the goods suggested by s. 61A of the Act? Or, alternatively, does the longer spell allowed by the Limitation Act avail the plaintiff and the terminus a quo start only when the owner has been finally refused delivery?

anchor.surface_text: Is the period so brief as six months in terms of s. 87 of the Bombay Port Trust Act, 1879  hereinafter called the Act , and if so, does time begin to run within around a week of the landing of the goods  suggested by s. 6lA  of the Act ? Or, alternatively, does the longer spell allowed by the Limitation Act

issues.text: The primary question is whether the present suit is one for any thing done, or purporting to have been done, in pursuance of this Act.

anchor.surface_text: The primary question is whether the present suit is one for any thing done, or purporting to have been done, in pursuance of this Act. The action is for non-delivery of one out of 53 bundles. plaintiffs counsel argues that an omission to do cannot be an act done or purporting to have been done.

the decisive date on which the decree turns and time runs has to be settled. if the Limitation Act applies, the suit, by any reckoning, is not barred but since it does not apply the critical issue is as to when time begins to run.

issues.answer: when consignee knows of landing and reasonable time for delivery elapses

issues.text: When does the statutory bailment take place and can the time for delivery to the owner of the goods arise before he knows or at least has good grounds to know that the bailment has in law come into being?

anchor.surface_text: the cause of action for short delivery comes into being only when the consignee comes to know that the bailment has come into existence.

issues.text: whether awareness of the factum of loss of goods is a sine qua non of the cause

anchor.surface_text: So we hold that awareness of the factum of loss of goods is not a sine qua non of the cause.

issues.text: the starting point of limitation is the accrual of the cause of action. Two components of the cause are important. The date when the plaintiff came to know or ought to know with reasonable diligence that the goods had been landed from the vessel into the port.

anchor.surface_text: The starting point of limitation is the accrual of the cause of action. Two components of the cause are important. The date when the plaintiff came to know or ought to know with reasonable diligence that the goods had been landed from the vessel into the port.

holdings.text: The short delivery of one bundle or rather the act of under-delivery in purported discharge of the bailees obligation under S. 61B of the Act is covered by s. 87 and the truncated limitation prescribed thereunder will apply.

anchor.surface_text: The logical conclusion of the legal study is that the short delivery of one bundle or rather the act of under-delivery in purported discharge of the bailees obligation under S. 61B of the Act is covered by s. 87 and the truncated limitation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Omission in course of statutory duty constitutes 'act purporting to be done in pursuance of Act'; supported by extensive precedents (Jolliffe, Privy Council, Federal Court, this Court); statutory scheme protects public bodies with short limitation.

holdings.text: An act includes an omission regardless of the General Clauses Act, when in legislations like the Act, and what is done under purported exercise of statutory functions, even if contrary, is done pursuant to the Act if legitimate link to official role.

anchor.surface_text: This chapter of our discussion yields the conclusion that an act includes an omission  regardless of the General Clauses Act, which does not apply to antecedent statutes -not under all circumstances but in legislations like the Act we are construing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inaction has activist facet; course of conduct under law includes omissions; precedents affirm protection for public servants/bodies despite negligence or default if nexus to duty.

holdings.text: The cause of action for short delivery comes into being only when the consignee comes to know that the bailment has come into existence.

anchor.surface_text: Brushing aside technicalities and guided by the analogy of art. 120 of the Limitation Act, we think it right to hold that the cause of action for short delivery comes into being only when

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right to sue postulates knowledge of bailment (landing); embryonic before knowledge; natural justice requires awareness of landing for accrual.

holdings.text: Awareness of the factum of loss of goods is not a sine qua non of the cause.

anchor.surface_text: So we hold that awareness of the factum of loss of goods is not a sine qua non of the cause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguish breach (non-delivery) from consequence (loss); knowledge of damage not needed for non-delivery suits; scienter for deterioration but not pure non-delivery.

holdings.text: The starting point of limitation is the accrual of the cause of action. Two components: date plaintiff knew/ought to know goods landed into port; reasonable time for delivery thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: The starting point of limitation is the accrual of the cause of action. Two components of the cause are important. The date when the plaintiff came to know or ought to know with reasonable diligence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Knowledge of landing essential; reasonable time per bulk delivery date or s.61A 7 days; search letters irrelevant post-knowledge.

holdings.text: When bulk consignment delivered on particular date, reasonable time for missing part is same date ordinarily.

anchor.surface_text: when the goods ought to be delivered can only mean the reasonable time taken

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pragmatic working rule; avoids uncertainty; exceptions need proof.

holdings.text: Letters or assurances that missing packages searched for cannot enlarge limitation once goods landed and owner knows.

anchor.surface_text: Letters or assurances that the missing packages are being searched for cannot enlarge limitation, once the goods have landed and the owner has come to know of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevents abuse, manipulation, corruption; tracing post-landing irrelevant per Bootamal analogy.

holdings.text: Starting point of limitation arose on November 7, 1959; suit June 18, 1960 beyond 6 months; barred.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, the starting point of limitation arose on November 7, 1959 and the suit was instituted on June 18, 1960, a little over 10 days beyond the period of limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Knowledge from vessel agents Nov 7; >6m to suit; notice tacked but immaterial.

holdings.text: Section 87 attracted not merely when act committed but also omission in course of official duty; act-omission complex with nexus to functions attracts s.87.

anchor.surface_text: Section 87 is attracted not merely when an act is committed but also when an omission occurs in the course of the performance of the official duty. The act-omission complex,

holdings.text: Statutory notice under s.83 condition precedent to cause, not constituent; 1 month may tack under Limitation s.15(2).

anchor.surface_text: Of course, the statutory notice under S. 83 is a condition precedent to, although not a constituent of, the cause of action And there is some authority for the position

anchor.surface_text: Judged by these working rules, the present case has to be decided against the plaintiffs. For one thing, the short delivery of one bundle of steel plates is an integral part of the delivery of the consignment by the port authorities to the consignee in the discharge of their official functions as statutory bailee. Section 87 of the Act, therefore, applies. The delivery of the bulk of the consignment took place on September 19, 1959 and more than seven months had passed after that before the institution of the suit.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; suit held barred by limitation under s.87 of Bombay Port Trust Act and dismissed

anchor.surface_text: Judged by these working rules, the present case has to be decided against the plaintiffs. For one thing, the short delivery of one bundle of steel plates is an integral part of the delivery of the consignment by the port authorities to the consignee in the discharge of their official functions as statutory bailee. Section 87 of the Act, therefore, applies. The delivery of the bulk of the consignment took place on September 19, 1959 and more than seven months had passed after that before the institution of the suit.
